Clearly, from the OP, Skepticgunt was using the term "creationist" in the generally understood sense, i.e., someone who believes that the earth was created in 6 literal days some 6,000 years ago. You, however, in an effort to appear superior, conflate that with anyone who believes in a god creator. Either you are ignorant of reality, or you are dishonest.
 
 We are all aware that there are "creationists" who believe a variety of things, some of them less intelligent than others. For example, there are the
 
 Flat Earth Creationists: Flat earthers not only believe that the universe was created in 6 literal 24 hour days about 6,000 years ago, they also believe that the earth is flat in spite of any evidence. Flat earthers are few in numbers and are generally laughed at by everyone, even other creationists. However, flat earthers are actually the only creationists who actually read the Bible literally, although others claim to do so. There used to be a web site of a flat earth christian organization that claimed a couple of hundred members. I've never met one.
 
 Geocentrists: A little more progressive, at least having moved forward to the 14th century, geocentrists recognize that the earth is a sphere, only they maintain that the earth is the center of the universe. I've actually run into two of these on the internet and there is a PhD physicist with a web site who is a geocentrist. Still, geocentrists maintain that the earth was created in 6 literal 24 hour days about 6,000 years ago. They read the Bible literally, all except for the parts where the earth is described as flat. Geocentrists don't seem to know the difference between "circle" and "sphere," two different words for two different geometric shapes even in ancient Hebrew. There aren't many geocentrists either.
 
 Young Earth Creationists: The most vocal of the creationists. These are the people of the ICR, Answers in Genesis, and ARN. These are the creationists who attempted to outlaw the teaching of evolutionary theory in high school biology, who invented "creation science" in an effort to replace real science, or at least get "equal time" for their religion in school science classes. This is "creationism" as it is understood by the vast majority of people when the word is used without modification. This I believe, is what SkepticGunt meant by "creationist." Since the speed of light is relevant only if one claims a young earth, then any other representation of the word in this discussion would be disengenuous. YECs interpret the Bible extensively in order to accept a spherical earth that orbits the sun and exists in one of billions of galaxies in the universe.
 
 Old Earth Creationists: There are several versions of old earth creationism. The lines between them are somewhat muddled. All are attempts to reconcile the Bible with reality. There are the Gap Creationists who claim that there was a large span of time between Genesis 1:1 and Genesis 1:2 in order to give the universe great age. And then there are the Day Age Creationists who claim that each day of the creation was really a vast age. Some Day agers even pretend that the order of creation in Genesis parallels reality as revealed by science. Progressive Creationists hold that the creation has been ongoing, with various exterminations and recreations of "kinds" throughout the long history of the universe. Progressive Creationists are more likely to accept some evolution within "kinds," a term rarely defined but usually fixed somewhere around the taxonomic classification of family. Of course, mankind is an exception, and not related to any other "kind" even though there is better than 98% similarity in the genes of humans and chimpanzees, and better than 96% similarity in other regions of the genome.
 
 Intelligent Design Creationists: IDers usually can fit into any of the Old Earth Creationist beliefs. It is rare to find a YEC who is willing to relax his dogma enough to accept ID.
 
 Theistic Evolutionists: These, like OECs, come in a range of beliefs that run from a personal creator god to a belief more like deism. Some may also be called "Evolutionary Creationists."
 
 Finally there are Materialist Evolutionists: This latter also incorporates a range of belief from the belief that nature must be explained by naturalistic causes (methodological naturalism) to those who assert that nothing exists except matter, energy and their interactions (materialistic naturalism).
 
 So there you go, Ringu. Clearly the discussion was originally intended to be about YEC. Now I'm not claiming that you can't broaden the discussion to the beliefs of other creationists who take the Bible less as reality and more as mythology, it's just that you need to be clear. Of course, the OP doesn't apply to most OECs, and you confuse the issue when you discuss them without making it clear that you are doing so.
 
 In the future, please be aware that "creationist" most usually means YEC on most discussion boards. If you can't figure it out by context, then ask instead of jumping in with ad hominem remarks that add little to the discussiion.

Radioisotope dating cannot be used directly on fossils since they don't contain the unstable radioactive isotopes used in the dating process. To determine a fossil's age, igneous layers (volcanic rock) beneath the fossil (predating the fossil) and above it (representing a time after the fossil's existence) are dated, resulting in a time-range for the fossil's life.
Essentially correct. Except that the fossil may or may not contain radioactive isotopes. The important concept is that they aren't useful for dating. They have been carried into the fossil by ground water and the source could never be determined.
 
So that said, again the material making up the rock is "whatever" age that doesnt mean the fossil is of the same age.
What it does mean is that a fossil is older than the age of the layer above that was dated, and younger than the layer below that was dated. The concept is actually quite simple.
 
Any sort of dating method used starts from the basis that the object being dated is alive in a closed system, in other words it assumes that the object is obtaining two seperate Carbons at the exact rate.
What terrible ignorance. There is no assumption of a closed system since they do not exist on earth. Nor does the object being dated have to have once been alive. The process that you started out discussing has nothing to do with carbon. What exactly do you mean by "two seperate [sic] Carbons?" How do you "obtain" a carbon at some exact rate? In order to give you a little help, whether an object being dated because it is between two geologic strata that can be dated has zero relevance to whether or not it was living. Tools made from rock can be placed in a certain range because they are found between two strata that can be dated radiometrically.
 
It also assumes that EVERY object is obtaining these Carbons at that exact same rate.
Obtaining what "Carbons?" Only one method of radiometric dating uses carbon, that is carbon-14 dating. Carbon-14 dating is useful only to date material that was once part of a living organism that had the air as its ultimate source of carbon. Moreover, C-14 dating is useful only to about 50,000 years. Please learn something before you speak. You are making yourself look like a fool. No fossil is dated because it "obtains Carbons." And you started so well by explaining that fossils are dated by the igneous layers above and below them before you relapsed into the dismal ignorance of "obtains Carbons at the same rate." C-14 dating relies on the fact that the object being dated has not been completely fossilized, i.e., there is still some organic carbon remaining.
 
In the same way that a piece of meat retains the seasons of the marinate, the fossil would retain some elements of the material surrounding it.
But as you explained, fossils aren't dated so any "marinate" [sic] is irrelevant. A fossil is essentially rock in which all of the organic compounds (including the carbon) has been replaced by minerals from ground water.  C-14 dating has been calibrated to about 45,000 years by dendrochronology and the C-14 dating of the varves in several lakes from around the world, as well as gases trapped in polar ice caps.  1) There is a type of bacteria that takes only 20 minutes to reproduce: to double. So let's start with a single bacterium. After another 20-minute interval we get a second round of division, giving 2^2 = 4 bacteria. After another 20-minute interval we get another - a third - round of division, yielding 2^3 = 8 bacteria.  2) It has been estimated that there are about 10^80 elementary particles in the known universe. That includes every proton, electron, and neutron, in every planet, moon, and star, in every solar system, in every galaxy, in every galaxy cluster: all of it.

The only form of creationism that could possibly come close to fitting into this evidence is Old Earth, Progressive Creationism, where God created every organism in the proper sequence to make it look like they shared common ancestors and have genuine phylogenetic relationships with eachother (even down to the same genetic markers in their pseudogenes) - a very unlikely proposition. YEC has already been proven false by radiometric dating (the Earth is 4 1/2 billion yrs old - not 6,000 yrs old) and by the sequence in the fossil record (contradicting the seqence in Genesis where flowering plants precede fish and birds precede reptiles). So the premises upon which evolution is built trumps those for creation any day.

Yes there is. The speed of light has been measured in outer space several times by several different methods.
 
 SN 1987 A was one event that has allowed the speed of light about 170,000 light years distant to be measured. SN 1987 A has a ring around it. That ring lit up shortly after the start went supernova. The ring is slanted in its presentation to earth, i.e., the top of the ring is closer to earth than the bottom. The first time the ring was lit by radiation from the SN, and since the star is in the center of the ring, in real time the whole ring lit at once. However, it appeared from earth that the top of the ring lit first, and that proceeded around the ring in both directions until it met at the bottom. The delay was caused by the increased distance the light from the bottom of the ring had to travel to reach earth.
 
 A second time the ring has been lit. This time it is from the shock wave from the SN. This lighting was predicted. It is proceeding from the top around both sides to the bottom once again. Indications are that the speed of light is still the same.
 
 One problem with your logic is that the "speed of light" is a maximum speed. There has never been any doubt that light can travel slower than that through some medium, like air, water, glass, etc. In fact, that is what causes rainbows and causes prisms to work. So anything that has an effect on the speed of light in space would tend to slow it rather than speed it up. However, gravity has the effect of red shifting or blue shifting the light. It still travels at the same speed in a vacuum. The expansion of the universe also red shifts the light - it still travels at the speed of light in a vacuum.
 
 So the result is that anything that could affect the speed of light would slow it down. Even if we were unable to detect that, the effect would be to make the universe older than we think it is. We think it is 13.7 billion years old, but if light were traveling slower distant objects would appear farther away.
 
 Certainly you "...have no way to prove this..." because there isn't any evidence to support that assertion. However, there is lots of evidence to the contrary. Besides, to presume that the laws of physics vary for no detectable reason through the universe is illogical in the extreme.
